Graphical abstract The assembling of MXenes at various interfaces to form various building blocks, including films, electrodes, aerogels, and other building blocks is summarized in detail. Mechanisms are explained. Applications of these architectures are also demonstrated. Two-dimensional (2D) transition metal carbides, carbonitrides and nitrides, known as MXenes, are emerging quickly at the frontiers of 2D materials world. Their exotic properties such as the highest electrical conductivity among all solution-processed 2D materials, the best electromagnetic interference shielding performance outperforming that of copper or aluminum at a nanoscale thickness, as well as the highest volumetric capacitance for pseudocapacitors, have been attracting extensive fundamental research and applications. Their unique surface chemistries, that is, hydrophilic groups terminated on the surface of MXenes after etching and delamination, enable plenty of opportunities for assembling into MXene building blocks. Particularly, assembling at liquid–liquid, liquid–solid, liquid–air, and solid–solid interfaces allows the efficient fabrication of various structures, including MXene surfactants, MXene heterostructures, MXene transparent films. Interfacial assembly of MXenes is of significance in unveiling more versatilities of MXenes as well as impacts on novel MXene-based architectures, based on which enhanced performance of devices is achieved. As such, this review focuses on the interfacial assembly of MXenes, explaining mechanisms behind various assembling and providing classical examples for corresponding interfacial assembling techniques. Applications of these as-assembled architectures are also discussed in brief. We believe this review may shed light on the interfacial chemistry of MXenes, thus guiding more efficient fabrication of MXene-based functional films/coatings/electrodes/devices. Keywords Interfacial assembly MXene Interfacial tension Crosslinking Heterostructures 1 Introduction on MXenes Transition metal carbides, nitrides, carbonitrides, so-called MXenes, have emerged as a rising family of two-dimensional (2D) materials [1–6], triggering extensive research in various applications ranging from electrochemical energy storage [7–14], water desalination [15], to electromagnetic interference shielding [16,17], sensing [18], radio-frequency identification [19–21], etc. MXenes possess a general formula of M n +1X n T x , where M is transition metal (such as Cr, Ti, V, Mn, Nb, Mo, etc), X is carbon and/or nitrogen, T x is the terminated surface groups (i.e.−OH, −O, −F, −Cl, −Br, −NH, etc), n = 1–4, and − ene symbolizes the analogue to graphene [3,22,23]. In general, MXenes are obtained through the selective removal of A atomic layers from MAX phases, where A is a group 13 or 14 element such as Al, Ga while M and X refer to the same ones in corresponding MXenes [1,24–26]. The first MXene member and the most extensively studied one is titanium carbide (Ti3C2T x ), which was discovered in 2011 through etching Ti3AlC2 in hydrofluoric acid (HF) [4]. Other MXenes, such as Ti2CT x [27], Nb2CT x [28], V2CT x [29,30], Mo2CT x [31], Nb4C3T x [32], Ta4C3T x [1], double-metal MXenes (i.e., Mo2Ti2C3T x , Mo2TiC2T x , Mo4VC4T x , etc.) [33,34], solid-solutions (i.e., (Ti0.5Nb0.5)2CT x , Ti3(C0.5N0.5)2T x ) [1], and in-plane ordered vacancies MXene (i.e., Mo1.33CT x ) [24,35,36], are also reported [22]. Up to now, >30 MXene members have been synthesized with hundreds are predicted to be thermodynamically stable [22,37]. Inherited from their MAX precursors, MXenes possess a hexagonal lattice symmetry coupled with excellent metallic conductivity up to 15,100 S/cm [38]. More importantly, such a metallic conductivity can switch to semiconducting behavior by replacing the M element [39,40]. On the other hand, single-layer MXene flakes allow the permission of 97% of visible light, indicating 3% of loss in transmittance per monolayer of MXenes (1.5 nm in Ti3C2T x ) [41–43], and surpassing that of graphene (2.3% loss per layer, 0.34 nm) [44,45] by taking the thickness into consideration. In other words, delaminated MXene flakes have shown quite promising applications in transparent conductive coatings [41,46], transparent sensors [47], light emitting diodes [39,48], and other fields that requiring a high transmittance as well as high electrical conductivity. Besides, MXenes are terminated with abundant groups such as −OH, −O, and/or −F on the surface after the selective removal of A element [49], rendering a good hydrophilicity on the resultant multilayered MXenes. The surface chemistry of MXenes can also be modified by halide molten salts etching (Lewis acidic etching) of the MAX phases [26,50]. As such, surface groups such as −Cl, −Br, −I, can be terminated on MXene surface [26]. Further reacting the molten-salt-etched MXene with other chemicals, these relatively weak-bonded halide groups can be substituted by −NH, −S or completely removed, enabling a fine tuning on the properties (electrical, optical, mechanical, magnetic, optoelectronic, photonic and phonic, band gap, work function, etc) [50]. The modifications of MXene surface chemistry imply strong impacts on the applications, including electrochemical energy storage [51–55], electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding, wave absorption, environmental protection, sensing, and others [56,57]. The major limitation that greatly impedes MXenes from practical application is their poor stability in water and/or humid environment [35,58–62]. According to Zhang et al., the oxidation starts on the edges of flakes and inwards afterwards; the pinholes/defects accelerate the oxidation kinetics [63]. Water and dissolved oxygen are two main reasons for the shortened life of colloidal MXene dispersions [64]. Based on this conclusion, isolating the delaminated MXene flakes from dissolved oxygen and/or water [64], storing in low-temperature environment [65], and/or capping the reactive edge of the flakes using polyanions [66] or antioxidant [61], have been confirmed as effective measures to realize stable colloidal MXenes with much extended shelf life. In addition, when the delaminated flakes are assembled with a compact morphology, the external nanosheets tend to form a protective layer upon long-term storage in ambient condition, resulting in films that well preserve the intrinsic properties of MXenes. These approaches highlight the importance of assembling techniques on the MXene shelf life. In line with this message, interfacial assembling of MXenes forming 3D aerogels can nicely and gracefully address most of these challenges related to poor stability and production costs. It is generally believed that once the surface of MXene delaminated nanosheets are accommodated with guest species, the oxidation stability kinetics is thus greatly suppressed through the capping effect. Moreover, the assembling with guest species requires a small amount of MXenes, which greatly reduces the MXene production cost. On the other hand, the rich surface chemistry coupled with the van der Waals force endow MXene with plenty of opportunities to assemble into MXene building blocks such as films, aerogels, heterostructures. at the liquid–liquid or liquid–solid interfaces. For instance, chemically grafting MXenes dramatically changes the surface tension as well as hydrophilicity of MXenes, leading to self-assembly of MXene flakes at the water–oil interface and formation of compact MXene films which are transparent and conductive [67,68]. By adding dispersions in which the guest species are positively charged into MXene dispersions, spontaneous assembly occurs at the liquid–solid interface where MXene-based composites are thus formed [69]. On the other hand, by adding dispersions with divalent metal ions, the electrostatic repulsive force of MXenes can be destroyed while the cation works as joining sites, leading to gelation at the liquid–solid interface and thus formation of MXene-metal ion hydrogel framework [70,71]. Upon freeze-drying, highly porous yet conductive sponge with excellent mechanical properties are obtained [17]. These MXene films, composites and aerogels can be widely applied as building blocks in many applications, such as conductive transparent coatings, electrochemical energy storage, drug delivery, sensing, EMI shielding, and so on. In other words, interfacial assembly of MXenes into MXene-based building blocks is of crucial significance toward the practical applications. While some reviews focusing on the MXene synthesis, properties and electrochemical energy storage applications have been published, quite few of them have reviewed the progress on the MXene assembling except a very recent one, which focused on the three-dimensional assembling of MXenes [72]. A timely review on the interfacial assembly of MXenes is highly in demand to provide insights on the fabrication of MXene building blocks for their emerging applications. As such, here in this review, progresses on the interfacial assembling of MXenes, including different assembling techniques, are discussed in detail. Surface chemistry, aqueous and organic dispersions of MXene are firstly discussed before heading to assembling. Interfacial assembling of pure MXene films and MXene-based composites are classified as two big categories, containing specific assembling routes such as physical/chemical grafting, electrostatic, heterogeneous and crosslinking assembling, gelation. Applications of these architectures are also briefly discussed, focusing on transparent conductive electrodes, electrochemical energy storage as well as electromagnetic interference shielding. Finally, challenges and prospects of interfacial assembly of MXenes are highlighted. 2 Important factors that governing the assembling of MXenes As mentioned before, the hydrophilic nature of MXenes is due to the presence of surface groups after the selective removal of A element (i.e. Al, Si, Ga) via solution etching of MAX phases [1]. These surface groups strongly influence the formation of stable colloidal dispersions (aqueous or organic), which further impact on the interfacial assembling of MXene flakes. As such, the surface chemistry of MXenes as well as colloidal behaviors are discussed prior to the MXene assembling. 2.1 MXene surface chemistry Previous studies indicate that the surface functional groups are etching route dependent. Etching MAX phases with a higher HF concentration (HF or LiF-HCl route) leads to multilayered MXenes with a higher F terminations [60,73,74]. For instance, HF-etched MXenes generally possess a higher F content compared to that of LiF-HCl route, since the concentration of HF in use is sharply different (>30 wt.% in the former vs. 3 wt.%–5 wt.% in the latter) [74]. In other words, LiF-HCl route leads to MXenes with a higher O/F ratio compared to that of HF route, which affects the colloidal behaviors and interfacial assembly as will be discussed below. As a result, quality, electronic conductivity, work function, band gap and other properties of MXene flakes are correspondingly changed [75]. For instance, a higher F surface terminations endow MXenes with higher work function up to ~5.3 eV while decreases to ~4.6 eV in the −O terminated Ti3C2T x [21,76]. The higher electronegativity of F than O also decreases the electronic conductivity in the resultant HF-etched MXene up to one order of magnitude (~1500 S/cm in the HF-etched MXene vs. ~15100 S/cm in the LiF-HCl-etched MXene) [21,77]. It's worth mentioning that etching route also affects the lateral flake size and their density of defects, a mild etching and delamination route generally results in MXene flakes with higher quality, larger flake size and less pin holes, thus exhibiting higher electronic conductivity compared to that of aggressive HF-etched MXenes [60,74]. While the presence of −F surface groups are inevitable in HF-containing etched MXenes, F-free MXenes (terminated with −O and −OH) can be obtained through hydrothermal reaction of MAX phase in concentrated sodium hydroxide deaerated solution at 270 °C [78]. On the other hand, halide surface groups can be grafted on the MXenes through Lewis acidic etching in halide molten salts. After etching at 750 °C, −Cl (or −Br, −I) and O-containing groups are added to the MXene surface [26]. It's worth mentioning that the surface bonding of Cl−Ti and Br−Ti (i.e., Ti3C2T x ) is relatively weak in terms of bonding energy and bonds formation enthalpies compared to those of F−Ti and OH−Ti [50]. As such, the halide-terminations can be modified by reacting with Li2Se, Li2O and NaNH2, yielding Ti3C2Se, Ti3C2O, and Ti3C2(NH) MXenes, respectively [50]. On the other hand, by reacting with LiH at 300 °C, these halide groups can be removed completely, resulting in bare MXenes (Ti3C2□2 and Ti2C□2) with vacancy sites [50]. This means that the surface chemistries of MXenes are fully under control; MXenes with certain type of surface groups can be manipulated to provide new structural and electronic properties, thus enabling new applications. Apart from chemical reactions, vacuum annealing is another effective route to remove surface groups [58,79]. For instance, by heating up MXene powders in Ar at high temperature, surface moieties are produced due to the partial removal of −OH groups [76,80,81]. It should be noted that the pristine hexagonal structure of MXene is maintained up to 800 °C, beyond which Ti3C2T x MXene starts to restructuring into cubic TiC crystals [79]. In any case, surface modifications affect the contact angle of MXenes and thus the dispersibility of MXene flakes in aqueous medium, influencing the interfacial assembly accordingly. 2.2 MXene colloidal behaviors Thanks to the abundant surface groups, the as-etched MXenes are hydrophilic and can disperse in water at ease. Indeed, by repeatedly washing the as-etched MXenes with de-ionized (DI-) water, the intercalated Li+ exchanges with water, causing swelling of the multilayered structure and finally leading to delamination once overcoming the weak interactions between the adjacent sheets. Meanwhile, repeated wash with DI-water also brings the pH of the dispersion to neutral, endowing zeta potential up to −80 mV in the delaminated flakes. This suggests that the as-delaminated MXene flakes are negatively charged and possess strong electrostatic repulsive forces, resulting in stable aqueous colloidal solutions. Nevertheless, the pin holes/defects on the delaminated MXene flakes catalyze the oxidation process, leading to quick degradation of the aqueous dispersions and thus limiting the interfacial assembly [64]. It's found that the dissolved oxygen and water are two primary factors that shorten the shelf life of MXene dispersions [82,83]. In addition, flake size also heavily affects the nanosheets stability [61,64,66]. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) studies revealed that oxidation starts from the edge and shreds the flakes toward inwards [64]. After oxidation, methane gas evolves above the Ti3C2T x aqueous dispersion while cloudy-white settles down on the bottom, which is TiO2 (anatase) [83]. Similarly, ammonium gas (NH3) may form after the oxidation of Ti3CNT x aqueous dispersion [83]. As such, synthesizing high-quality MXene flakes with few pin holes, storing the aqueous dispersions in Ar-filled hermetic vials and keeping them in a low-temperature environment (5 °C) significantly improve the shelf life of delaminated MXene flakes [64]. Very recently, it's found that after freezing the aqueous dispersions at −20 °C, the quality of MXene flakes is maintained after two years [65]. Apart from these energy-intensive methods, capping the active edges with polyanionic salts such as polyphosphates, polysilicates or polyborates) is effective to mitigate oxidation [66]. Similarly, adding antioxidant such as sodium L-ascorbate is also capable to minimize the oxidation degradation of the flakes, maintaining the pristine properties of MXenes even after months of room-temperature storage [61]. It's thus worth mentioning that the removal of these added salts adds additional steps in the subsequent processes, complexing the whole procedures. On the other hand, by completely replacing water with non-aqueous polar solvents, direct contacts of MXene flakes with these two oxidants are thus eliminated, ensuring much extended shelf life in MXene-organic dispersions [84]. In general, good organic solvents are those that minimize the solvent-nanosheets and solvent–solvent interactions [85]. N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), dimethylformamide (DMF) possess high dielectric constants (and thus a high solvent polarity index), suggesting a stronger capability to stabilize the negatively-charged Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets [86]. In other words, organic solvents with relatively high polarity can disperse Ti3C2T x nanosheets much better than solvents with lower polarity such as ethanol and methanol. This is evidenced by the much higher MXene concentration achieved in NMP than in methanol [84]. From the concentration-Hansen solubility parameter (dispersion Hansen parameter, δ D, polarity Hansen parameter, δ P, and the hydrogen-bonding Hansen parameter, δ H) plots, it was found that good organic solvents for Ti3C2T x MXene typically possess not only a high polarity δ P, but also a high dispersion interaction strength (δ D) [86]. This well explains why MXene flakes disperse well in NMP, DMSO, DMF and water, since these solvents exhibit a high strength of both polarity and dispersion interactions. Water has an unusually high hydrogen bonding strength as well. On the other hand, for solvents (such as methanol) that possess a low polarity δ P and/or moderate dispersion interactions (δ D), quite limited amount of MXene nanosheets can be dispersed, resulting in a much lower concentration (<0.1 mg/mL in methanol). Ethanol disperses MXene flakes better than methanol and dispersions with a concentration of 0.5 mg/mL may be achieved [84]. Despite MXene organic dispersions can be prepared through multiple solvent exchange without sonication, their concentrations are relatively low [87]. 3 Interfacial assembly of pure MXenes 3.1 Definition of interface and interfacial assembly Due to the interlayer interactions as well as the high surface-to-volume ratio in the delaminated flakes, restacking of 2D nanosheets is common for all 2D materials ranging from graphene, transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), and boron nitrides to MXenes [88–91]. The high surface tension coupled with van der Waals force in the delaminated MXene flakes also lead to aggregation, despite the electrostatic repulsive force on their surface. As such, investigating the coupling phenomenon at the interface and initiating the interfacial assembling are expected to guide the “aggregation” in purpose but also to produce novel architectures with exotic properties, such as enhanced electronic conductivity, improved gas permittivity, boosted sensing gauge factor, strengthened mechanical properties and so on [72,92,93]. Here in this review, interface is defined as the boundary of two (or three) phases, including liquid–liquid, liquid–solid, liquid–gas, solid–solid and solid–gas interfaces (Fig. 1 ). As explained before, MXene flakes are able to disperse in solvents with a high polarity δ P and a high dispersion interaction strength δ D, forming stable colloidal solutions with flakes homogeneously distributed. Therefore, through adding organic ligands that pre-dissolved in “MXene bad solvent” to the MXene dispersions, the interfacial tension is decreased and MXene compact yet transparent films are assembled at the liquid–liquid interface (for example, water–oil interface) [68,94]. On the other hand, by purging CO2 gas to the multilayered MXene powders at 800 °C, MXene-based heterostructures consisting of external oxides “shell” and internal carbide “core” are obtained at the solid–gas interfaces [95,96]. Similarly, by utilizing the abundant electronegative surface groups as anchoring sites for metal cations, quantum dots (for example, SnO2)-MXene [69,97] and carbon-plated MoS2-MXene heterostructures [98] can be obtained at the liquid–solid interfaces, endowing thrilling opportunities in many fields such as Li-ion batteries, water splitting, sensing, etc. Therefore, MXene microscale assembling at different interfaces (instead of only focusing at the liquid–liquid interface), covering formation of pure MXene films, 3D macroassemblies, heterostructures, and hybrids, are of significance, and will be discussed in detail as below. 3.2 Assembly of delaminated MXene flakes As mentioned before, MXene surface is terminated with abundant hydrophilic, electronegatively charged groups, ensuring formation of stable colloidal solutions when dispersed in water. This unique nature endows facial interfacial assembly of MXene in the aqueous medium in the liquid–liquid, liquid–solid and liquid–air interfaces. For example, after dropcasting MXene aqueous dispersion on Si substrate, upon continuous evaporation of water in the liquid–air interface, smooth films are automatically assembled in the liquid–solid interface, ensuring Schottky contacts with n-Si and thus enabling the separation/transport of photoinduced carriers in photodetectors [99]. On the other hand, through creating MXene ligands, the latter spontaneously migrates to the immiscible boundary such as water–oil interface, and proceed the interfacial assembly [67,68]. These unique assembled films typically possess good flakes alignment, a compact film morphology and thus showing good electronic conductivity. Indeed, the MXene assembly in the liquid–air interface is pH-dependent. When pH > 8, directly MXene monolayer-assembly is achieved with thickness ~ 1.5 nm, ensuring the formation of continuous transparent conductive films. When pH < 4, the as-assembled MXene films are terminated with coordinated anions such as Braq − [100], as shown in Fig. 2 (a). Such a pH-control assembly process has further proven in the formation of MXene-based emulsions. Due to the interactions of positively charged − N(CH3)3 on cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) with − O groups on MXenes (Fig. 2b, top panel), the hydrophilicity of MXenes can be tuned and stable emulsions are thus enabled (Fig. 2b, bottom panel) [101]. For pH < 7 (acidic medium), protons undermine the CTAB-MXene bonds thus emulsions become unstable. On the other hand, when pH > 7, stable water-in-oil emulsions (known as Pickering emulsions) are enabled. Further freeze-drying-annealing results in the construction of 3D MXene foams [101]. By utilizing the evaporation of high vapor pressure (or low-boiling point) of solvent (such as ethyl acetate, 77.1 °C, Hexane, 68.7 °C or dichloromethane, 39.6 °C), constant turbulence is created, based on which 2D flakes (such as graphene) start to assemble at the water-exposed regions on the surface due to the Marangoni effect [102]. Kim et al. suggested that the turbulence resulted from the floated layer of ethyl acetate (EA) on water lead to Rayleigh-Bénard convection, forming regions with high surface tension and driving fluctuating MXene flakes into films, which can be further compacted through breaking the repulsion between individual MXene sheets via adding HCl droplets [47]. As such, transparent MXene films are obtained (Fig. 2c, top panel), which exhibit a typical sheet resistance of 310 Ω/□ under an optical transmittance of 80%, despite apparent flake corners or junctions are visible according to the scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Fig. 2c, bottom panel) [47]. On the other hand, through tuning the pH of as-obtained MXene solution, followed by addition of EA, flexible, transparent MXene films (Fig. 2d) whose film thickness can be precisely adjusted through assembling different layers (Fig. 2e), are assembled at the water–air interface [103]. The assembling mechanism relies on two steps. First, the addition of EA creates a strong vertical Rayleigh-Bénard convection due to the endothermal evaporation of EA, the convection further delivers the suspended MXene flakes from the entire dispersion to the water–air interface. Second, the Marangoni effect derived from surface tension difference between water and EA, drive the floated MXene flakes into a densely packed film in a similar manner to that of pristine graphene films [102]. The two-step assembly mechanism is schematically illustrated in Fig. 2(f). For some occasions, strong yet flexible MXene fibers are more preferable compared to planar MXene films. To this end, engineering delaminated MXene flakes into highly conductive fibers is of significance. Through controlling the concentration of MXene colloidal dispersion, one can realize MXene liquid crystal (LC) phases that can be spun into strong and conductive fibers, holding great promises for flexible and wearable electronics [87,104–108]. Despite adding LC surfactant and single-walled carbon nanotubes (or graphene oxide [105]) lead to a “composited” MXene-based LC, with improved ion transport kinetics [108], these LC additives need to be removed in order to restore the pristine properties of MXenes, compromising the scalable feasibility. Importantly, by adjusting the aspect ratio as well as ink concentration, pure MXene nematic LC phase can be achieved [107]. Upon extruding aqueous MXene LC inks, the shear force lead to long-range orientational ordering of the delaminated flakes in the fine nozzle, which further result in pure MXene fibers after solidification in the coagulation bath, as schematically demonstrated in Fig. 2(g) (left panel). Coagulation rate is of importance during the MXene flakes assembly; a faster coagulation rate (i.e. acetic acid) resulted from the rapid solvent exchange leads to fibers with loosely packed nanosheets, while a slower coagulation rate (i.e. chitosan) leads to fibers with densely packed flakes, as demonstrated in Fig. 2(g) (right panel) [107]. Aside from the LC phase formation, the ratio of storage modulus to loss modulus (G′/G′′) can be used as the indicator for the spinnability of 2D LC colloidal dispersions [109]. Since MXene concentration governs the rheological properties of the delaminated solution [9,110] therefore, through tuning the concentration of colloidal MXene dispersions, one is able to achieve stable pure MXene fibers with strong gel strength. For instance, a lower concentration generally leads to a high G′/G′′ ratio, suggesting a weak gel strength that prevents the formation of stable MXene fibers. On the other hand, as the MXene concentration goes beyond 15 mg/mL, the G′/G′′ ratio reduces to 5.29, indicative of strong gel strength enabling successful spinning into pure MXene fibers with highly oriented, compacted nanosheets [111], as seen in Fig. 2(h). One needs to bear in mind that cations from the coagulation bath may greatly enhance the gelation of MXene fibers, due to the MXene surface is electronegatively charged. For instance, Han et al. suggested that the extruded MXene failed to form gel fibers without NH4 + in the coagulation bath [111]. Other hybrid fibers based on MXene-polymer (i.e. PEDOT [112]) [87], MXene-GO [112], MXene-CNT [113], and yarns based on MXene-cellulose [104,114], are also reported. 3.3 Interfacial grafting of MXenes 3.3.1 Physical grafting As mentioned before, the rich electronegatively charged groups on MXene surface enable plenty of opportunities to perform surface modifications. To this end, strategies on physical grafting the surface of MXenes are reported, relying on the physical ionic interaction between negatively charged MXene and positively charged species, such as CTAB [101]. Similarly, by direct mixing positively charged polystyrene (PS) with MXene dispersions, the nanosheets homogeneously wrap the PS spheres. By immersing in toluene, the PS spherical core are removed while the hydrophobic long chain is grafted to one side of MXene nanosheets, forming Janus MXene nanosheets that exhibiting both hydrophobicity and hydrophilicity [68]. These Janus MXene nanosheets (or so-called MXene surfactants) facilitate the interfacial assembly into microdroplets (which can be further processed into 3D MXene aerogel assisted by freeze-drying) or nanofilm at the liquid–liquid interface upon emulsification and aging, respectively (Fig. 3 a). In other words, interfacial assembly between two immiscible liquids (in this case, MXene aqueous solution and oil phase) allows the formation of functional building blocks and further mesoscale or even macroscale architectures (aerogels, films, etc.) at ease [67], opening vast opportunities for advanced membranes, electrodes, sensors, gas adsorption, and so on [115]. For instance, the oil-soluable amine-terminated polyhedral oligomeric sisesquioxane (POSS-NH2) is able to cooperative assemble with the negatively charged MXene surface, forming Janus MXene surfactant rapidly at the oil–water liquid–liquid interface and further developing into Janus MXene assembly when jammed [67]. Through further emulsification, Pickering emulsions are thus obtained, serving as template for hydrophobic, isotropic MXene aerogels (Fig. 3b) with excellent mechanical properties and electromagnetic interference shielding performances [16,67]. Reasons behind the interfacial assembling for the Janus MXene surfactants lie in the reduced interfacial tension induced by the POSS-NH2 from the oil phase and MXene from the aqueous phase, as evidenced in Fig. 3(c, top panel), sharing a similar kinetic model (bottom panel) of graphene oxide nanosheets and diblock copolymers [116,117]. Indeed, these jammed micro-droplets of MXene surfactant may function as structured liquids with arbitrary geometries, paving the road to three-dimensional (3D) printing of one liquid in another liquid, such as silicone oil or toluene [118–120]. By applying some external perturbation (i.e. mechanical force, moving the print head), interface area is increased, allowing additional MXene surfactants to populate at the newly formed interface. However, once the perturbation is removed, the whole system tends to minimize the surface area (or interfacial energy) through relaxation, yet is impeded by the jamming of MXene/n-butylamine (ligands) surfactants. As such, stabilized geometries consisted of MXene surfactants are obtained [120] (Fig. 3d). 3.3.2 Chemical grafting Beside the abovementioned physical grafting approaches, chemical grafting of MXene allows the preparation of organic dispersions at ease with much extended shelf life [86]. Typically, chemical condensation between hydroxyl groups of MXenes and alkoxy or chloro groups on alkylsilane (i.e. fluorinated or amine-terminated alkylsilanes [121–123]) is employed to chemically modify MXene surface in an alcohol or alcohol/water system. Considering the poor dispersion stability of MXene in alcohol, as well as the homocondensation of silane ligands in aqueous medium, one should choose a different ligand to give stable colloidal organic dispersion. For instance, by mixing MXene aqueous acidic solution with alkylphosphonic acid ligands dispersion, chemical condensation reactions occur at the liquid–liquid interface, leading to chemical grafting of the long hydrophobic tail to MXene nanosheets assisted by the formation of covalent TiOP bond [94] (Fig. 3e). Such chemically grafted MXene flakes are stable in organic dispersions in the absence of potential oxidation, and can serve as the building blocks for further assembling into macromonoliths in non-aqueous medium. Aside from chemical condensation to graft organic tails to MXene flakes, annealing of amines or other polymers is another way. For instance, Ti3C2T x MXene was decorated with −NH2 groups from annealing of allylamine [124]. These grafted groups endow significantly increased interfacial interaction between MXene flakes and common elastomers, such as nitrile butadiene rubber (NBR), through the formation of hydrogen and covalent bonding [124]. Likewise, poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA)-coated Si particles prefer to assemble with MXene nanosheets at the solid–solid interface due to the strong interfacial interaction between PMMA and MXene (Fig. 3f). Further annealing at 500 °C leads to the removal of PMMA and formation of SiOTi covalent bond that endowing Si nanoparticles with good mechanical stability [125]. Other methods, such as ball milling, are also capable to create new chemical bonds at the solid–solid interface [126,127]. 4 Interfacial assembly of MXene-based composites After discussing the assembly of pure MXenes in thorough, interfacial assembly of MXene-based composites also deserves to be paid attention, since MXene-enabled functional composites have already demonstrated splendid promising applications in various areas covering catalysis, energy storage and conversion, sensing, and wearable electronics and so on [8,11,13,97,128–131]. To differentiate “composites” formed in the pure MXene assembly since additional polymers or surfactants are required to assist the jamming of MXene flakes or formation of chemical bonds (see Section 3), here composites are defined as combination of key components (exclude ligands) acting a critical role toward specific application, and the amount of guest species is much higher compared to the amount of ligands required for pure MXene assembly. 4.1 Electrostatic assembly Electrostatic assembly is a powerful technique to realize “electrostatically layer-by-layer (ELBL)” assembly of two oppositely charged building blocks with an atomic precision at the nanoscale [132], serving as the main tool in manipulating thin films, coatings, clustering, colloids, capsules, supramolecules and others toward different applications [133–140]. In principle, electrostatic assembly relies on the alternative adsorption of the two building blocks through direct mixing procedure [132]. The main drawback of electrostatic assembly lies in the initial dilute mixing concentration to avoid potential interparticle bridging, which limits the yields of resultant precipitants [132]. Delaminated MXene nanosheets are predominantly single-layer, exposing a large surface area to guest species and thus being an ideal platform to proceed the electrostatic assembling. For those metallic MXenes, the thin lamellas function as conductive backbone, facilitating electron transport kinetics across the as-assembled multilayers. To achieve these multiscale MXene-based composites via the electrostatic assembly route, one needs to ensure the guest species are positively charged. This can be done either through surface modifications [141–143], such as cation surfactant coating [144], annealing amines to impart −NH2 groups [124,145]. or choosing species with intrinsic positive charges (such as graphitic-C3N4) [146]. Another big challenge is to disperse these guest species homogeneously in water, a process which may involve sonication despite the latter may change the size, thickness or even composition of the guest species. Polymers, in particular polystyrene (PSs) [147] and polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) spheres [148], are frequently employed as the building blocks to perform the electrostatic assembly with MXene dispersions. This is because PSs (or PMMA) are positively charged due to the assist of cationic surfactant as stabilizer and comonomer during dispersion polymerization [149]. Upon mixing the two solutions, MXene flakes spontaneously wrap PSs or PMMA spheres, driven majorly by the electrostatic force as well as hydrogen bonding (due to surface hydroxyl groups) and van der Waals (vdWs) forces, and MXene-wrapped PSs or PMMA spheres (Fig. 4 a) are obtained [68,147,148]. It's worth noting that MXene content influences the architecture and assembly mechanism of hybrid spheres; a low amount of MXene nanosheets leads to a continuous assembly on the PS spheres primarily driven by the electrostatic forces, excessive nanosheets not only results in the neutralization of the surface charges of spheres electrostatically, but also initiates MXene self-assembly driven by the hydrogen bonds or vdWs forces, leading to PSs tightly covered by MXene interconnected network [147]. Using cation surfactant grafting method to impart positive charges to guest species (such as carbon nanotubes, CNTs, oxides) is an important step to proceed electrostatic assembling procedure. These surfactants include polyethyleneimine (PEI) [136], CTAB [150], poly(ethylene glycol), and others [101,144,151,152]. For instance, CNTs are grafted with CTAB surfactant, the latter endows positive charges on the hydrophobic CNTs (see the positive zeta potential in Fig. 4b, bottom left panel), rendering homogeneous aqueous dispersions (Fig. 4b, bottom right panel). Upon mixing two dispersions, CTAB-CNTs are attracted and grafted on the MXene flake surface, thereby the negative charges of MXene are screened and aggregations appear with clear supernatant is observed, indicative of successful electrostatic self-assembly [134]. Other composites, such as Fe3O4/C@MXene [153], amine-terminated Si/MXene [154], CTAB-CNT/MXene [150] or PEI-CNT/MXene [136], can be similarly fabricated as electrodes for Li-ion capacitors, Li-ion and Li-S batteries, respectively. The major disadvantages of physical grafting method on guest species are (1) one needs to remove these grafted polymers or surfactants, otherwise the conductivity of the composites would be greatly compromised, since these surfactants/polymers are large molecules impeding the electron transfer paths; and (2) realizing hybrids that are electrostatically assembled at atomic level is rather challenging. Solutions to issue 1 include but not limited to choose guest species that are intrinsically positively charged, such as graphitic C3N4 [146], layered double hydroxides, LDH [155–158], and the like [159]. Porous graphitic C3N4 exfoliated from bulk and protonated was reported to possess the zeta potential of 21 mV, serving an ideal building block to fabricate MXene-C3N4 heterostructures/interfacial Schottky junction (Fig. 4c) for various catalytic applications, including H2O2 production [146], hydrogen evolution [160], photocatalytic CO2 reduction [161]. On the other hand, LDHs intrinsically contain positively charged metal hydroxide host layers, rendering the electrostatic assembly quite favorable with intrinsically negatively charged MXene flakes. Exfoliated edge-rich CoAl-LDH/MXene heterostructure (Fig. 4d) [162], and CoMo-LDH/MXene hybrids [163] were reported, demonstrating a strong feasibility in fabricating multiscale functional composites with excellent applications. Solution to issue 2 includes using positively charged, yet small molecules, i.e. tris(2-aminoethyl) amine (TAEA), to assemble with MXenes. Such a process allows the assembly at atomic level (interlayer spacing expands by only 1 Å) with quasi-intimate small gap, thus the composites are compact, ordered and highly conductive (conductivity up to 730 S/cm) [164]. It's worth noting that the fine tuning of d-spacing enabled by TAEA molecules ensures strong interconnections among flakes, the slightly expanded interlayer spacing still improves the ion diffusion kinetics for enhanced energy storage properties [164]. 4.2 Heterogeneous assembly On the other hand, the rich surface chemistry of MXene suggests plenty of wet-chemistry choices to perform interfacial engineering, achieving efficient heterogeneous assembly with various multiscale architectures. These nanostructures include 0D/2D [97,165,166], 1D/2D [128], 2D/2D/0D heterostructures [167] and other combinations. Indeed, the surface groups on MXenes facilitate the heterogeneous nucleation of guest species, achieving the in-situ growth of guest species (ranging from 0D quantum dots to 3D structures) that strongly attach to the 2D MXene platform through either electrostatic force or interfacial bonds [165] or covalent bonds [94], and forming so-called hierarchical heterostructures. For instance, cations such as Ni2+ and Fe3+ prefer to attach to MXene nanosheets due to the strong interfacial interaction with polar −OH groups. Further hydrolysis and olation/oxolation of MO6 (M = Fe, Ni) units enable the in-situ growth of 2D NiFe-LDH/MXene hybrids (as shown in Fig. 5 a) [156]. Actually, similar LDH/MXene heterosturctures can be similarly assembled using this route [162]. The heterogeneous nucleation method can also be extended to other oxides, assembling into transition metal oxides/MXene hybrids such as SnO2/MXene, at the liquid–solid interface [97]. Furthermore, methods of tuning MXene surface chemistry have also been reported either through Lewis acidic molten salt etching to enrich the surface groups (−Cl, −Br, −I) [26,168] or completely remove these surface moistures [50], suggesting a large room for heterogeneous assembly of MXene-based composites. Typically, heterogeneous assembly requires a hydrothermal treatment of the blend suspension of MXenes-precursor of guest species in order to accelerate the nucleation/growth stage of the latter. However, under the hydrothermal condition, MXene nanosheets tends to be decayed due to the attack of water and dissolved oxygen [64]. To address this issue during heterogeneous assembly, one needs to cap the edge/basal planes of delaminated MXene flakes either through covering a layer of oxides [97], or carbon [98], or polymer [169] that proceed with a faster reaction kinetics compared to that of MXene oxidation under the same hydrothermal condition. For instance, Zhang et al. confirmed that the well coverage of in-situ nucleated SnO2 seeds on MXene nanosheets is the reason for the preservation of the conductive backbone from oxidation after hydrothermal reaction at 120 °C [97]. Based on this strategy, a broad range of MXene-based heterostructures with good electron and ion transport pathways can be similarly assembled for energy storage, catalysis, sensing etc., with state-of-the-art performance. Another good example is by formation of interfacial bonds between black phosphorous quantum dots and MXene nanosheets. The as-formed POTi interfacial bonds greatly assist interfacial electron transfer and interfacial structural stability of the composite [165], showcasing excellent electrochemical performance for Li-ion and Na-ion storage. When solution mixing MXene aqueous dispersions with guest molecules (in particular biomass, surfactant, resins, block copolymers, etc.), hydrogen bonds are typically formed between MXene nanosheets and guest molecules coupled with electrostatic interactions to reduce the total surface free energy. Therefore, through subsequent treatments (i.e. hydrothermal, polymerization, carbonization), one is able to convert these pre-assembled superstructures to carbon-coated MXenes (as shown in Fig. 5b) [169]. It's worth noting that the plated carbon well protects the MXene surface from oxidation under hydrothermal or annealing at high temperature, thus can serve as a 2D platform for further growth of multiscale heterostructures based on carbon-plated MXenes. In particular, Wang and Qiu et al. reported hierarchical MoS2/carbon-plated MXene heterostructures via the heterogeneous assembly of in-situ converted MoS2 (from the reaction of molybdate tetrahydrate with thiourea) onto MXene (Fig. 5c). The nanoplated carbon function as a thin layer of protective membrane for MXenes from being oxidized at hydrothermally reacting at 160 °C, and a “glue” for MoS2 such that heterostructures are formed with good electron transfer kinetics and mechanical stability [98]. This novel carbon nanoplating route for extending the stability of MXene flakes suggests limitless choices for heterogeneous growth of other guest species (i.e. MoSe2 [170]) on MXenes with good electron/ion transport kinetics and excellent interfacial binding interactions. Actually, the selective, mild oxidation of layered MXene lamellas also creates hierarchical MXene-oxides heterostructures in-situ [171,172]. For instance, annealing multilayered Nb4C3T x and Ti3C2T x MXenes in CO2 flow lead to the formation of Nb2O5/carbon@Nb2CT x and TiO2/carbon@Ti3C2T x heterostructures, respectively [96]. These oxides locate at the external of the heterostructures, which are strongly attached to the unoxidized multilayered MXenes core through the carbon “glue” [95,96]. Since the oxides are grown from the pristine MXene at the solid-air interface, therefore, good electrical conductivity is maintained and strong adhesion at the oxides/MXenes junctions are expected, ensuring excellent performances in batteries [95,171], catalysis [173], microwave absorption [174], and other applications [175]. Aside hydrogen bonding, covalent interaction is another route to proceed the heterogeneous assembly of MXene-based composites. Through harnessing the interlayer spacing of MXene lamellas, S can be covalently intercalated into pretreated MXenes, forming Ti − S covalent bonds in the interface [176]. On the other hand, MXene nanosheets can be employed to functionalize graphene oxide (GO) platelets based on the TiOC covalent bonds, resulting in more aligned and compact graphene sheets with enhanced mechanical toughness [177]. These two examples clearly indicate that, utilizing the interfacial covalent bonding between MXene sheets and other guest species, synergistic effects such as improved electrical, mechanical and electrochemical properties are anticipated in the as-assembled MXene-based heterostructures. Despite these abovementioned strategies in fabrication of MXene-based hybrids, assembling heterostructures still inevitably involve high temperature and/or pressure. While pristine structures of Ti3C2T x MXene may be persevered under the harsh conditions, other MXenes (in particular, Ti3CNT x , V2CT x , Ti2CT x , etc.) may not survive upon hydrothermal/annealing treatments. To this end, initiating the heterogeneous assembly under ambient conditions is of great significance. Xu and Gogotsi et al. have shown that by minimizing the high surface energy of MXene flakes using oxides (such as TiO2, SnO2) in MXene's poor solvent (i.e. tetrahydrofuran, THF), the poor dispersibility of MXene flakes can be greatly addressed, forming micelle-like TMO-MXene heterostructures spontaneously via vdWs interactions (Fig. 5d) [178]. Such a vdWs route driven by the surface tension at the interface to the assembly of MXene-based heterostructures is general, and effective in growth of other 2D materials (i.e. GO [179], MoS2 [180], hexagonal boron nitride, h-BN [181]), holding great promising in low-cost synthesis of advanced heterostructures at room temperature. 4.3 Crosslinking assembly and gelation Compared to planar compact MXene-based films and structures, three-dimensional (3D) architectures assembled from 2D nanosheets possess apparent advantages, such as more developed porosity, readily exposed active sites, lightweight nature, and improved ion diffusion kinetics. In addition, the fabricated 3D monolith well preserves the structural, electrical and electrochemical properties of its 2D nanosheets. As such, constructing 3D macroassemblies based on 2D nanosheets is of significance. This is especially true for the formation of MXene-based 3D aerogels/monoliths, as MXenes have already demonstrated a huge potential in ultralight electromagnetic interference shielding [103,182–184], wireless communication [19–21], and other cutting-edge technologies that prefer lightweight materials without compromising the key features substantially. Nevertheless, the as-assembled MXene 3D aerogels, if not challenging in preparation, are typically brittle and fragile (tensile strength of a MXene film was reported as 20 MPa [185], much lower than that of a graphene film) that they can't withstand too much stress. This is because the intrinsic interaction of MXene nanosheets is weak, leading to a low tensile strength [129]. Moreover, the as-prepared MXenes (etched from LiF + HCl route) typically contain Li+ even after repeated washing [74]. Pristine MXene 3D aerogels encounter the structural swollen and further disassembly issues if they are placed in deionized H2O, due to the ion exchange of the as-intercalated Li+ with water molecules [186]. As such, improving the structural stability of the preassemblies is of paramount importance for the realization of MXene-based 3D macroassemblies (monoliths/aerogels). One solution is to stabilize the preassemblies' microstructure by tuning the intercalation chemistry of MXenes [73,187]. To this end, Li et al. exchanged the intercalated Li+ with hydrated protons via thawing the unidirectional MXene/ice hydrogel in protic acids (HCl, HBr, H2SO4, etc.), leading to pure MXene hydrogel matrix with significantly suppressed hydration [186]. Interestingly, without the acid thawing, the pre-assembly get solvated and redispersed into solution thus no 3D matrix is formed (Fig. 6 a). This can be explained that the removal of Li+ prevents the intercalation of H2O, a process energetically favored by the presence of Li+ with a large hydration enthalpy [186,187]. Another strategy is to initiate crosslinking by choosing guest species as gelation agents. The anisotropic intersheet crosslinking effect renders the formation of MXene-based hydrogel pretty challenging, due to the super hydrophilic nature of this wonder 2D materials [188]. Graphene oxide is a perfect gelation agent for MXenes, since it possesses inherent flexibility and is able to neutralize the rigidity of the MXene flakes [71], thus has been widely employed to initiate the macroscopic assembly to give graphene-MXene hybrid aerogels [70,188,189]. A typical crosslinking process is shown in Fig. 6(b), where GO interact with MXene sheets at sites of oxygen dangling bonds, forming MXene hydrogels [71]. During crosslinking, a GO reductant (such as ethylenediamine, EDA [71], and ascorbic acid [17]) is required. Selection of the reductant poses a significant influence on the macroscopic assembly. Reductants with ring-opening of epoxy groups are able to crosslinking with GO layers via nucleophilic reactions to form oxygen dangling bonds [190,191]. Too strong (such as NaBH4) or too weak (i.e. KOH) reductants lead to excessive or inadequate reduction and thus no MXene-rGO hydrogel is formed. Moreover, the reductant should provide crosslinking sites for both MXene flakes and partially reduced GO, based on which the assembly of MXene flakes are driven by the vdWs force and supported with rGO nanosheets through the π–π interaction, as shown in Fig. 6(c) [71]. Inappropriate reductants would either lead to oxidation of MXene or formation of rGO hydrogel. It's worth mentioning that the as-assembled hydrogel is consisted of randomly distributed MXene nanosheets [71,72]. For applications (such as electromagnetic interference shielding) that preferring ordered porous channels, engineering the alignment of nanosheets becomes crucial. To this end, directional freezing of as-assembled hydrogel has proven effective in producing unidirectional aerogels [129,192]. Such a strategy relies on the growth of ice cylinders, which expel the rGO and MXene sheets to the external surface, and compel them to assemble among the vertical ice cylinders (shown in Fig. 6d) [17]. Following the removal of ice template via freeze-drying, MXene-based aerogels with ordered slit channels, and a honeycomb-lattice morphology is obtained (Fig. 6d and e) [17,129]. On the other hand, by employing polar chains obtained through interfacial polymerization, the tensile strength of as-fabricated MXene-based aerogels can be dramatically enhanced. For instance, annealing poly(amic acid) (PAA) initiates the polymerization of PAA, forming polyimides macromolecules that strongly covering on the MXene nanosheets surface through interfacial bonding (Fig. 6f). The coupling between PI chains and surface groups of MXene nanosheets results in hybrid aerogel with outstanding mechanical properties, in particular reversible compressibility with large strain up to 80% [193]. The weak gelation of MXene nanosheets in pure, pristine MXene aerogels can also be much improved through introducing strong hydrogen bonds between −OH/−O groups on MXene flakes and abundant −OH/−COOH groups on sodium alginate (SA). By optimizing the composition and further coating a polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) layer, 3D hybrid MXene-SA aerogels with excellent electrical conductivity (up to 20 S/cm), compressibility and durability are thus achieved (Fig. 6g) [194]. Aside from GO, polymers [93,195] and biomass (such as nanocellulose [129]) to initiate crosslinking, metal cations can also be used to trigger the gelation of MXene nanosheets, similar as metal ion-induced solid–liquid interfacial assembly of graphene oxide [196]. Divalent metal ions, i.e. Fe2+, are able to destroy the electrostatic repulsion force among MXene nanosheets (step 1) and further crosslink the nanosheets into 3D network by forming FeO bonds (step 2), as seen in Fig. 7 (a and b) [70]. Other metal cations are also able to initiate the gelation of MXene flakes (Fig. 7c), with divalent metal ions (i.e. Mg2+, Co2+, Ni2+, etc.) being the most preferable. This is because that univalent K+ ions possesses poor hydration energy and leads to coagulation upon mixing (Fig. 7c), while trivalent metal ions (such as Al3+, Fe3+, Co3+) inevitably leads to fast destroy of the repulsion force, indicative of aggregation of MXene nanosheets, coupled with potential risks of MXene oxidation [70]. The concentration of MXene dispersion also matters when comes to the formation of MXene hydrogel mediated by metal ions. Another model to assemble MXene hydrogel, and further aerogel (through freeze-drying) is through so-called ion-diffusion-induced strategy, which typically requires a piece of metal foil, such as Zn foil. Such a process is similar to the preparation of large-area rGO paper on the Zn foil surface [196]. The key to the gelation of MXene and/or GO nanosheets is the ionization of Zn in the acidic solution, forming Zn2+ and increasing the ionic strength of the local dispersion near the substrate [197]. Thereby, negatively charged MXene and/or GO nanosheets start to aggregate underneath the substrate, while at the same time GO is partially reduced into rGO by accepting electrons from Zn, forming a MXene-rGO hydrogel and further a robust aerogel (Fig. 7d and e) [183]. The pore size and thickness of the aerogel are governed by pH value of the initial suspension and gelation time, respectively. According to the Zn K-edge X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), intense signal belonging to ZnO bonds are observed (Fig. 7f), suggesting Zn2+ as gelation sites coordinating with oxygen atoms from MXene and GO, similar to that of the metal ion-induced assembly mechanism stated above [70,183,194]. Other metal foils such as Al, Co, Fe and Ni foils, etc., are also able to initiate the interfacial assembly of MXene and/or GO nanosheets in the acidic solution, forming macroscopic architectures with exotic properties. Such a metal ion-diffusion-induced strategy is also capable to scalable produce large-area, robust MXene-based hybrid aerogel (Fig. 7g). 5 Applications of assembled MXene architectures After interfacial assembly, the as-obtained MXene architectures typically preserves the intrinsic properties of MXene flakes, i.e. electronic/ionic conductivity, mechanical strength, polar surface, etc. suggesting promising applications in different fields (Fig. 8 ). This is especially true when applying the MXene assemblies in fields such as transparent conductive electrodes, energy storage, electromagnetic interference shielding, environmental protection (water treatment) [198–202]. 5.1 Transparent conductive electrodes (TCE) Transparent conductive electrodes are important components for electronics. Ideal TCEs should exhibit both high optical transmittance (T) and low sheet resistance (R s). The figure of merit (FoMe), defined as the ratio of DC conductivity to optical conductivity, is generally accepted to evaluate the optoelectronic properties of the film; a higher value of FoMe indicates films are more conductive at a given thickness. 1D CNT and 2D graphene or rGO are employed as TCEs for specific applications, however, the FoMe of pristine graphene is typically limit below 0.5 [44,203]. Doped graphene may exhibits quite high FoMe that is comparable to indium tin oxide (ITO), yet involving complicated procedures [204]. MXene on the other hand, possesses extremely high electronic conductivity (up to 15,100 S/cm [38]). In addition, transmittance of single-layer MXene nanosheets is as high as 97%, which is even more transparent compared to graphene at a given film thickness, since single-layer graphene (thickness of graphene is 4 times higher than that of MXene single layer) results in 3% loss in transmittance [43,205,206]. These unique properties render MXenes quite promising in applications such as touch panels, flexible displays, sensors. For instance, the self-assembled film reported by Kim et al. displayed a low sheet resistance of 310 Ω/□ at a thickness of 10 nm, corresponding to a conductivity of 3260 S/cm [47]. The lower conductivity of interfacial-assembled MXene films compared to that of spin-casted MXene film (DC conductivity up to 10,000 S/cm, FoMe up to 15) can be attributed to the relatively loose compact of nanosheets in the former [43,46]. Koo et al. found that when assembled into monolayer MXene film, the transmittance was 90% and R s was 1500 S/cm, which gradually decreases with increasing the stacking number. Importantly, the sheet resistance of as-assembled MXene films drops dramatically upon thermal annealing at 400 °C [103], due to the decreased interlayer spacing (rendering improved contacts among interlayers) coupled with the removal of water molecules. By sieving the particle size and/or optimizing the composition of MAX precursor, ultrathin films self-assembled from delaminated MXene flakes may exhibit even more outstanding optoelectronic properties. Needless to say that interfacial assembly of transparent MXene films holds a great promise for high-end applications, if these films can be assembled at a large scale. 5.2 Electrochemical energy storage (EES) 5.2.1 Supercapacitors One of the important properties for MXenes is their extraordinary performance in electrochemical energy storage, EES, in particular supercapacitors and rechargeable batteries [9,36,84,108,131,207,208]. This is because of the metallic conductivity as well as hydrophilic groups in the single-layer nanosheets, enabling continuous valance change of the M atomic layer thus leading to high pseudocapacitance, both gravimetrically and volumetrically [6,208–212]. However, the vdWs forces lead to severe restack of MXene nanosheets, which strongly affects the ion diffusion paths and further reduces the capacitance. To this end, engineering vertically-aligned MXene nanosheets has proven effective in addressing the sluggish ion diffusion kinetics [108]. Through the assistance of surfactant and sequent mechanical shear, MXene nanosheets are assembled (with surfactant via hydrogen bonding, Fig. 9 a) and highly aligned, forming liquid crystal film with the director being perpendicular to the shear direction (Fig. 9a). As such, directional ion diffusion paths (Fig. 9b) are created in the MXLLC, ensuring excellent capacitance at high charging rate (200 F/g at 2 V/s, Fig. 9c) that is independent with electrode thickness within the range of 200 μm [108]. The self-assembled MXene architecture with vertical alignment of nanosheets suggests fascinating applications in fields beyond EES, including filtration, fuel cells, catalysis. This also implies that the precise manipulation of directional assembly of functional materials like MXenes offers plenty of opportunities to build advanced nanostructures with exceptional performances [108]. Nevertheless, reports and strategies on the directional alignment of MXene assemblies need to be more investigated, as evidenced by the quick capacitance (or capacity) decay as ramping the charging rate. Other MXene-based assemblies also displayed outstanding capacitance and rate handling properties. For instance, MXene hydrogels provides rapid ion transport and excellent electronic conductivity, resulting in high volumetric capacitance up to 1500 F/cm3 [213]. MXene macroporous electrode (25 μm) produced via electrostatic assembly assisted by spherical templates, on the other hand, exhibited 280 F/g at 1 V/s and maintained 120 F/g at 10 V/s, which can be attributed to the developed porous channels to facilitate the rapid ion transport, as evidenced by the much reduced ion transport resistance compared to that of MXene hydrogels or vacuum-filtrated compact papers [213]. In other words, due to their pseudocapacitive site on the nanosheets surface, interfacial-assembled MXene or MXene-based architectures are promising supercapacitor electrodes, whose rate performance can be enhanced through pillaring effect [130,214,215], intercalants [73,164], or porosity engineering [70,71,216,217]. 5.2.2 Rechargeable batteries Aside from supercapacitor, the as-assembled MXene architectures also exhibit promising applications in rechargeable batteries (Li+, Na+, K+, etc.). The unique 2D sheets morphology coupled with outstanding electronic conductivity and mechanical properties endow MXene assemblies as high-performance electrode materials, or as 3D matrix/host for the guest species. For instance, the heterogeneous nucleated SnO2 seeds on MXene nanosheets effectively suppress the restack of MXenes while opening more favorable ion diffusion paths, resulting in high capacity (1021 mAh/g) when employing the SnO2 QDs/MXene assemblies as Li-ion battery anode [97]. On the other hand, the 3D macroporous V2CT x MXene film possess developed voids which greatly facilitate Na+ diffusion (Fig. 9d), best evidenced by the nondiffusion limited and pseudocapacitive mechanism when storing Na+ [148]. The electrode showcased 340 mAh/g at 0.25C (4 h to complete charging), maintained 310 mAh/g at 2.5 C after 1000 cycles and retained 170 mAh/g at 25C (2.4 min of charging time), implying excellent Na ion storage capacity benefited from the unique architecture design as well as broaden initial interlayer spacing [148]. Employing other low-dimensional nanomaterials (such as 0D quantum dots [69,165], 1D nanotubes [134], nanorodes and nanowires [178]) to enlarge the interlayer spacing in the resultant MXene-based assemblies is just another route to boost their metal ion (Li+, Na+, K+, etc.) storage performance (including capacity, rate, cycling and resistance). For instance, SnO2 QDs, which possess a high theoretical Li-ion storage capacity, exhibit excellent capacity up to 890 mAh/g coupled with stable cycling performance achieved in the interfacial-assembled composites [69,97]. CNTs are also effective in turning the sluggish Na+ transport kinetics, which has been confirmed in stacked MXene nanosheets [218,219], into non-diffusion limited, pseudocapacitive behavior (Fig. 9e) when comes to store Na+ in the electrostatic-assembled CNT-MXene heterostructure [134]. Despite the extensive studies on MXene assemblies for rechargeable battery applications, several challenges still deserve to be paid attention. These challenges include but not limited to: (1) Engineering more ion-favorable channels in the MXene-based assemblies at a low-cost, straightforward route without losing the electronic conductivity dramatically has proven quite difficult; (2) precisely controlling the MXene nanosheet stacking behavior such that both electronic and ionic conductivity in the assemblies are well balanced is still quite challenging; (3) scalability and compatibility of the assembly process with standard battery electrode fabrication procedures should be evaluated; (4) stability of the resultant MXene-based architectures should be emphasized. Electrochemical tests of both fresh, as-assembled MXene-based composites and aged ones in ambient condition should be performed and compared in order to ensure reasonable results interpretation. Besides, interfacial-assembled MXene structures should be prepared via routes with low-carbon emission. 5.3 Electromagnetic interference shielding (EMI) Another important application for the MXene assemblies is electromagnetic interference shielding (EMI). Vacuum-filtrated MXene films have shown excellent EMI shielding performance due to their metallic conductivity, surface reflection, bulk reflection and multiple internal reflections among the interlayers [182,184]. However, filtrated MXene films are typically compact, rendering the maximum usage of interlayers rather challenging. In this sense, MXene-assemblies may exhibit improved EMI shielding performance by enlarging interlayer spacing [103,220], constructing ultralight aerogels [17,129,183,221], and/or creating more sites for multiple internal reflections [17,147]. Koo et al. performed pioneering works on MXene for EMI shielding applications [182,184]. Recently, they confirmed that monolayer MXene assembled film offers ~20% shielding effectiveness of incident EM waves, whereas assembled, semi-transparent MXene film (55 nm in thickness) demonstrates a shielding effectiveness (SE) of 20 dB, corresponding to 99% of incident EM waves are shielded [103]. This is the first report on transparent EMI shielding materials that possess such a high SSE/t (specific SE normalized to film thickness), surpassing all other nanomaterials including nanoscale metals such as beam-evaporated Au (Fig. 9f) [103]. For these electrically thin MXene films (thickness below skin depth, calculated to be 7.86 μm for a MXene film with electrical conductivity of 5000 S/cm), absorption of incident EM waves dominates the shielding behavior, which can be well explained using the transfer matrix method [103,182]. Increasing the thickness of the as-assembled MXene structures generally results in the improvement of SE. For instance, MXene-GO assembled films demonstrated EMI SE of 50.2 dB at a thickness of 7 μm, and increased to 53.5 dB as increasing the thickness to 12 μm [220]. On the other hand, since the absorption mechanism majorly dominates the EM waves shielding behavior, one can realize enhanced EMI SE through creating more sites for EM waves absorption, such as 3D architectures, foams, aerogels. 3D MXene-sodium alginate (SA) aerogels, which possess strong hydrogen bonds such that the aerogels are capable to withstand compressions, exhibit a high EMI SE of 70 dB when MXene content is 95%. This indicates that 99.99999% of incident EM waves are shielded when passing through the MX-SA foams [194]. Other interfacial-assembled structures, such as MXene-polystyrene [147], MXene-rGO aerogels [17] which showcased a maximum of 62 dB (adding 1.9 vol% of Ti3C2T x MXene to PS) and 50 dB (adding 0.74 vol% to GO), respectively. Especially, the MXene-nanocellulose aerogels assembled through hydrogen bonding and fabricated via unidirectional freeze-drying strategy demonstrated an ultralow density down to 1.5 mg/cm3 and a highest EMI SE of 74.6 dB [129]. This corresponds to a normalized surface specific SE (SSE/t) of 189400 dB cm2/g, which significantly surpassing that of other EMI shielding materials or structures reported so far (Fig. 9g) [16,129]. Table 1 summarizes various interfacial assembled MXene-based architectures (including interfaces and assembly routes) and their corresponding potential applications. In general, assembly technique literally determines potential applications. Interfacial assembled pure MXene films are typically compact and transparent, therefore are especially suitable for transparent conductive films, transparent energy storage and other fields that requiring ultrathin conductive films with excellent volumetric performance. For instances, films assembled at the liquid–air interfaces driven by the Marangoni effect are conductive yet transparent, rendering promising applications such as transparent conductive coatings. On the other hand, the applications of interfacial assembled MXene-based composites depend on both techniques and the assembled interfaces. For instances, grafting (both physically and chemically)-induced electrostatic assembly of MXene-based composites are particularly suitable for energy storage, while cross-linking induced assemblies are ideal for mechanical reinforcement, gelation induced MXene-based composites are quite promising for electromagnetic interference shielding, to name just a few. 6 Summary and perspectives To summarize, here in this review, MXene-based architectures assembled at various interfaces, including liquid–air, liquid–liquid, liquid–solid, solid–solid and solid-air, are discussed in detail. Pure MXene assemblies well preserve the pristine properties of MXene nanosheets, and are especially promising for applications such as transparent conductive electrodes, EMI shielding, as well as transparent energy storage devices. For pure MXene assembling, one needs to overcome the electrostatic force among the nanosheets, either through lowering down the interfacial tension, or creating Rayleigh-Bénard convection to proceed the nanosheets self-assembly. For MXene-based composites, the fabrication is majorly relied on the unique surface chemistry of MXene, that is, electronegative polar groups like –OH, –O, –F. These groups electrostatically attract the guest species, or facilitate the heterogeneous nucleation, or initiate gelation which results in crosslinking of the nanosheets. Consequently, 2D hybrid films, 2D macroassemblies with micro 3D structures, and 3D aerogels are achieved. These multiscale architectures may find plenty of applications ranging from electrochemical energy storage to sensing, catalysis, environmental protection, EMI shielding and so on. Interfacial assembly of pure MXene films is the most straightforward route to realize compact, transparent, conductive coatings, thus are quite promising for transparent conductive electrodes, transparent energy storage, and transparent EMI shielding applications. However, due to the nanometer scale thickness, these as-assembled films tend to degrade in the ambient environment. Methods to protect the as-assembled films from oxidation need to be developed without sacrificing the transparency and conductivity. On the other hand, interfacial-assembled MXene based composites, ranging from grafting, electrostatic assembling to crosslinking and gelation are especially suitable for constructing thick electrodes or even 3D macrostructures, such as aerogels. These MXene architectures possess excellent charge storage performance and EMI shielding effectiveness. Nevertheless, the assembling process is more sophisticated, and the electronic conductivity of as-assembled composites is much lower, limiting their applications in fields that preferring high electrical conductivity. Despite the progresses on MXene assemblies achieved so far, there is still much room to further improve the rational design of assembled MXene architectures. First, understanding how surface chemistries precisely control the assembling behavior between MXene nanosheets and guest species. In particular, replacing–OH groups with other terminations (i.e. −Cl, −Br, −I, etc.) change the density of surface charges accordingly. Unraveling such changes and further investigating their influences on the assembling behaviors, are of paramount importance. Second, engineering the porous channels during assembling is still quite challenging. Despite the unidirectional freeze-drying method is effective, the pores are rather macroporous with the pore diameter up to 50 μm [129]. For applications that favoring a high specific surface area, i.e. energy storage, EMI shielding, assemblies with fine micro-mesoporous channels and thin walls are preferred. Thus, strategies are aiming to prepare such kind of MXene assemblies. Third, stability of as-assembled films has been largely unexplored. It's necessary to evaluate the stability of MXene assemblies, especially those assembled at the water interfaces. Thus for assemblies proceeded at water-containing interfaces, it's significant to determine whether water molecules are intercalated, as water molecules oxidize MXenes; methods to remove these oxidants should also be developed. Besides, thermal stability of the as-assembled MXene structures should be performed. Finally, for MXene-based assemblies aiming to real applications, large-scale interfacial assembly should be facilitated. This not only requires scalable production of MXene stable colloidal solutions, but also demands for scalable, advanced assembling techniques. It's also important to point that, despite MXene possess exotic properties in electrical, mechanical, electrochemical, electromagnetic fields, however, how to translate their unique properties into real devices with state-of-the-art performance is another story. To this end, more efforts are needed in fabrication of functional devices enabled by novel interfacial assembled MXenes. It goes without saying that these MXene assemblies will trigger broad applications. coredata.dc:description: Two-dimensional (2D) transition metal carbides, carbonitrides and nitrides, known as MXenes, are emerging quickly at the frontiers of 2D materials world. Their exotic properties such as the highest electrical conductivity among all solution-processed 2D materials, the best electromagnetic interference shielding performance outperforming that of copper or aluminum at a nanoscale thickness, as well as the highest volumetric capacitance for pseudocapacitors, have been attracting extensive fundamental research and applications. Their unique surface chemistries, that is, hydrophilic groups terminated on the surface of MXenes after etching and delamination, enable plenty of opportunities for assembling into MXene building blocks. Particularly, assembling at liquid–liquid, liquid–solid, liquid–air, and solid–solid interfaces allows the efficient fabrication of various structures, including MXene surfactants, MXene heterostructures, MXene transparent films. Interfacial assembly of MXenes is of significance in unveiling more versatilities of MXenes as well as impacts on novel MXene-based architectures, based on which enhanced performance of devices is achieved. As such, this review focuses on the interfacial assembly of MXenes, explaining mechanisms behind various assembling and providing classical examples for corresponding interfacial assembling techniques. Applications of these as-assembled architectures are also discussed in brief. We believe this review may shed light on the interfacial chemistry of MXenes, thus guiding more efficient fabrication of MXene-based functional films/coatings/electrodes/devices.
